title: 113_hr497
content: The "America Works Act" is the short title of this legislation. Congress finds that there is a shortage of skilled workers in manufacturing, with 600,000 positions unfilled. These positions are mainly in skilled production roles like machinists and technicians. A loss of expertise is expected as millions of workers retire. Attainment of postsecondary credentials is key for workforce readiness. The Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts 746,500 new jobs in computer-related fields. The Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts a 23 percent net growth in computer-related occupations, with the highest projected growth rates in database administrators, software developers, and network and computer systems administrators. As of June 2012, there were approximately 301,214 job openings in the information technology sector. Certifications are highly valued by managers hiring for IT jobs, especially by senior managers and medium-size firms. SEC. 3. Training programs under the Trade Act of 1974 may prioritize workers seeking approved training programs. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "industry-recognized" refers to a credential accepted by employers in the industry sector, endorsed by a trade association, and nationally portable. "Recognized postsecondary credential" consists of an industry-recognized credential. The curr_chunk describes various types of credentials for postsecondary training, including industry-recognized credentials, certificates meeting specific requirements, completion certificates for apprenticeship programs, and associate or baccalaureate degrees from higher education institutions. The Act does not mandate selecting programs with recognized postsecondary credentials. The Act and its amendments take effect 120 days after enactment.
